column4: I want to connect to a vnc server at home from elsewhere.  Which ports do I need to forward on my router so that vnc sessions can be accessed
thank you very much
may I ask how you found this information?
I've been using VNC for years, I just know it ;)
add more numbers to 5901 if you run more than 1 server.

I would like to pick your brain a bit.  I have a cable modem > wireless router AP > 3 rooms down WIRELESS router in Client mode.  router1 forwards ports to rotuer 2, which in turn runs the little subnet in my room.  I want to connect to my desktop using vnc, but go through all those.  I can configure my NAT no problem, but how can I add a bit more security to this?
any advice?
if I run vncserver on :1 while :0 is my real desktop, will I be able to use my original desktop somehow?
does vnc allow to connect to already running desktop or must I start a new session in :1
I do not know.  Unfortunately, most of my VNC knowledge is based on Windows installs.
read above.
As far as I know thats not possible in gnome.
well I had originally said that I like kde becase it has what gnome doesn't.  someone asked me what, and so i told them
I thought you were asking a question, sorry.
oh no :)
Yes.
from which debian release?
to some extent at least, Packages made specifically for debian may not work properly, but .debs made for ubuntu work fine.
18th.
